results.title: Silent speech (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A study of non-verbal communication in young children featuring the work of biologist Prof. Hubert Montagner who has discovered a correlation between the behavior of children and the attitudes of the mother toward the child. He also suggests that physiological changes in the mother - specifically the level of various hormones - are mirrored in the child. Made by British Boradcasting Corporation.

results.title: Green machine (Plants)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Coverage of the life of a green plant. The work involved in the plant producing its own food is discussed as it the importance of this process to an overall understanding of ecology. Implications for the future with respect to harvesting energy and food with this process are also raised.

results.title: The Other way
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documents the ideas of E.F. Schumacher, a British economist who is deeply concerned with dwindling fuel supplies, myths about modern technology, and the loss of human worth in 20th-century consumer production. Emphasises his idea that many modern machines use too much energy and that there is a need to develop an intermediate technology of machines that consume less energy. Commentary by Ian Holm.

results.title: You are old, Father William
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Describes what happens to our mind and bodies as we grow older. Recent research into the physiology. Biochemistry, and psychology of old age is discussed. The processes of aging are many and complex and work at different rates. Although science is far from able to increase the maximum life span of human being. More and more people can live longer in better physical and meal health.

results.title: The Death star
results.creator_credit: Karen Kelly and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
This is the fascinating story of the discovery of the “hypernova” and perhaps the key to the mystery of how stars are created. Astronomers and scientists have been baffled for many decades since the first US satellite launched in 1967 detected bursts of gamma rays - the deadliest form of energy known - of an intensity and scale so massive that Einstein’s law of mass and gravity, E=mc2, began to be challenged by some astronomers. Theories and hypotheses of where exactly these massive explosions were taking place, ie within our own galaxy or somewhere further out in the universe, were being put forward from renowned astronomers across the globe and it wasn’t until 30 years later in 1997 that the mystery began to unfold and scientists were able to pinpoint the exact location of the bursts. Through interviews with various astronomers including Prof. Bohdan Paczynski, Prof. Martin Rees and Prof. Stan Woosley, an informative discourse is offered on the theories of the creation and formation of the universe; the Cosmic “dark age”; gamma rays; neutron stars; black holes; and the death and birth of stars or stellar synthesis and the hypernova. Containing some spectacular images created by computer animation this program both informs and entertains at the same time. Narrated by John Shrapnel.

results.title: Brave new babies?
results.creator_credit: Oliver Morse, David Dugan and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Introduces some of the new developments in genetic engineering including gene mapping, cloning and embryo manipulation. Argues that we should sort out our attitude to genetic engineering now before biology catches up with science fiction.

results.title: The Hot-blooded dinosaurs
results.creator_credit: Robin Bates, Robin Brightwell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Challenges our conventional ideas of dinosaurs. Argues that they were not slow-moving, cold blooded reptiles, but were agile, intelligent and hot-blooded. Points out that they didn’t all die out and that their descendants are alive and well and living all around us.

results.title: The Lost waters of the Nile
results.creator_credit: Alec Nisbett, KRO-TV Hilversum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Report on the issues surrounding the construction of the Jonglei Canal, a massive engineering project intended to bypass an enormous area of marshland formed by the waters of the White Nile. Considers in particular the effects on the Dinka people who inhabit the area and the difficulties facing the builders of the canal.

results.title: The Chemical dream
results.creator_credit: Edward Goldwyn and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Looks at the research and utilization of enzymes in industry and the mass production of bacteria that produce specific enzymes. Also the production of sugar from carbohydrate source is discussed, together with its implications in the sugar-cane industry. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
